resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

fields.summary: [R] Add extra documentation for test_dplyr_equal helper function

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

thisisnic commented on pull request #11403:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11403#issuecomment-943115640


   Also, how about if we swap the arguments around so that the data frame or vector to be tested is the first argument, and then the expression is next? It fits the tidyverse pattern of data-first functions, and feels more natural to refer to a special variable like `.input` *after* its contents have been defined.


--

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11403#discussion_r730920258

File path: r/tests/testthat/helper-expectation.R
##########
@@ -64,24 +65,31 @@ verify_output <- function(...) {
   testthat::verify_output(...)
 }
 
-#' @param expr A dplyr pipeline with `input` as its start
-#' @param tbl A tbl/df as reference, will make RB/Table with
-#' @param skip_record_batch string skip message, if should skip RB test
-#' @param skip_table string skip message, if should skip Table test
-#' @param warning string expected warning from the RecordBatch and Table paths,
+#' Compare dplyr binding
+#'
+#' Comparing the output of running expressions on R objects against the same
+#' expression run on Arrow Tables and RecordBatches.
+#'
+#' @param expr A dplyr pipeline which must have `.input` as its start
+#' @param tbl A tibble or data.frame which will be substituted for `.input`
+#' @param skip_record_batch The skip message to show (if you should skip the RecordBatch test)
+#' @param skip_table The skip message to show (if you should skip the Table test)
+#' @param warning The expected warning from the RecordBatch and Table comparison paths,
 #'   passed to `expect_warning()`. Special values:
 #'     * `NA` (the default) for ensuring no warning message
 #'     * `TRUE` is a special case to mean to check for the
 #'      "not supported in Arrow; pulling data into R" message.
 #' @param ... additional arguments, passed to `expect_equal()`
-expect_dplyr_equal <- function(expr,
-                               tbl,
-                               skip_record_batch = NULL,
-                               skip_table = NULL,
-                               warning = NA,
-                               ...) {
+compare_dplyr_binding <- function(expr,
+                                  tbl,
+                                  skip_record_batch = NULL,
+                                  skip_table = NULL,
+                                  warning = NA,
+                                  ...) {
+
+  # Quote the contents of `expr` and evaluate it to get the expected value

Review comment:
       _Capture_ instead of _quote_? Maybe evaluate it as regular {dplyr} syntax.




--

dragosmg commented on pull request #11403:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11403#issuecomment-945798743


   A more general comment. Would it make sense to replace `expect_equal()` with `expect_identical()` inside `expect_dplyr_equal()`? I feel Arrow is quite strict about type and we're not enforcing a strict check for equivalence with a dplyr call. 
   For example, I was surprised to see the {dplyr} call returning an integer and the equivalent {arrow} call returning a double. That's due to `expect_equal()` being less strict than `expect_identical()` - i.e. it has a built in tolerance when checking values (small floating point differences are ignored). This implies that `1L` and `1` are treated as equal.  


-- 
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.

To unsubscribe, e-mail: github-unsubscribe@arrow.apache.org

For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

thisisnic commented on a change in pull request #11403:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11403#discussion_r731601929



##########
File path: r/tests/testthat/helper-expectation.R
##########
@@ -64,24 +65,31 @@ verify_output <- function(...) {
   testthat::verify_output(...)
 }
 
-#' @param expr A dplyr pipeline with `input` as its start
-#' @param tbl A tbl/df as reference, will make RB/Table with
-#' @param skip_record_batch string skip message, if should skip RB test
-#' @param skip_table string skip message, if should skip Table test
-#' @param warning string expected warning from the RecordBatch and Table paths,
+#' Compare dplyr binding

Review comment:
       Maybe some explanation would clarify things here.  Binding, from the word bind, as in to tie things together.  We've bound the Arrow C++ functions to other libraries' function names (via `nse_funcs`and the function maps).  These tests are technically used for implementations of methods (e.g. `arrow::mutate_dplyr_query()`) which aren't quite bindings, but perhaps close enough.
   
   I was wanting to avoid terms like "expression" just as we have Expression objects which relate to Arrow Expressions and I think this would potentially lead to additional confusion.




-- 
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

-expect_dplyr_equal <- function(expr,

thisisnic commented on pull request #11403:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11403#issuecomment-946470772


   > A more general comment. Would it make sense to replace `expect_equal()` with `expect_identical()` inside `expect_dplyr_equal()`? I feel Arrow is quite strict about type and we're not enforcing a strict check for equivalence with a dplyr call. For example, I was surprised to see the {dplyr} call returning an integer and the equivalent {arrow} call returning a double. That's due to `expect_equal()` being less strict than `expect_identical()` - i.e. it has a built in tolerance when checking values (small floating point differences are ignored). This implies that `1L` and `1` are treated as equal.
   
   It's an intentional decision for reasons I can't recall, but @nealrichardson might know the answer to that one.


--

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

fields.description:
Possible things to do:
* rename this function so it doesn't break people's model of how {{expect_*}} functions work
* add inline comments to chunks to simplify
* add a description in the oxygen header to describe in a few sentences what it's doing
